sentences.sentence: Last month's federal budget had something for everyone, including makers and sellers of contraband tobacco.

Their unexpected gift came in the form of a $4 per carton increase in excise duties on legally manufactured and sold cigarettes, a sharp increase that may mark the end of one era - in which tax policy was an effective tool to control tobacco use - and the beginning of another.A bit of background will help.
Historically, Ottawa and the provinces have both taxed tobacco products with two objectives: raising revenues and discouraging tobacco use.

They have not always been able to "have their cake and eat it too," however, for the more they curtail tobacco use the less revenue they make.To preserve their respective shares of the tax pie, they have to go toe-to-toe on tax rates and also contend with the inconvenient fact that when up to 80 per cent of the retail price of a legal product is composed of tax, huge profits can be realized by sellers of untaxed contraband.Followers of game theory and economic behaviour will recognize what happens when strategic cooperation between governments is replaced by competition.
Back in 1991, a $6 per carton excise increase was announced in that year's federal budget as a health measure to discourage smoking.
But it was also designed to make up lost ground: though provincial governments had been repeatedly raising their tobacco taxes the federal government had not been so active.

When the feds did bring in their $6 hike, the provinces immediately matched it.In no time, untaxed cigarettes smuggled across the border via the Akwesasne Mohawk Reserve that straddles the New York, Ontario and Quebec borders began to flood the Canadian market.
While enforcement and seizures ramped up, contraband's share of the legal market jumped from one per cent in 1987 to 31 per cent in 1993 as smokers switched to lower-cost options.

The only measure that ultimately proved effective in stemming the tide was a coordinated federal/provincial rollback of tax increases in 1994 - after which the profit motive evaporated and the smuggling declined as quickly as it had started.The moral of this story?

In a zero-sum game, an aggressive move by one party can elicit an equally aggressive response by another, leaving both worse off in the end.Largely because of this experience, when cannabis was legalized in 2018, federal and provincial governments agreed to impose a relatively modest combined tax rate - the higher of either $1 a gram or 10 per cent of the producer's sale price, plus HST and a 25/75 federal/provincial revenue split: cooperation rather than competition.On the tobacco control front, both levels of government were coming to recognize that incremental tax increases elicited less of a substitution response than sudden, sharp spikes.
In 2014, the federal excise duty on tobacco products was indexed to inflation and adjusted every five years.

In 2016, Ontario announced it would base future increases on inflation over the next five years, and in the 2018 federal budget, this adjustment was accelerated to occur annually instead of every five years.
And the feds threw in an immediate increase of $1 per carton for good measure!Fast forward to the present.
The indexed federal increase for 2021 was implemented as planned on April 1 - which made the additional $4 per carton increase just three weeks later on budget day that much more of a surprise.

While sellers of contraband were no doubt well pleased, provincial finance officials were far less likely to be enthusiastic as all provinces except British Columbia had already tabled their 2021 budgets.
When B.C.

tabled its budget two days after Ottawa, it added a whopping $6 per carton increase of its own.For those who don't believe tobacco smuggling is a serious problem, last November the Canada Revenue Agency released a study estimating the loss in federal excise duty revenue from illegal cigarettes - the so-called "tax gap" - at about $483 million in 2014.
Lost provincial tax revenues would more than double that estimate.

And the gap has likely widened in the seven years since.Terence Corcoran: From beer to billionaires, massive tax grabs are here(https://financialpost.com/opinion/terence-corcoran-from-beer-to-billionaires-massive-tax-grabs-are-here)Opinion: Health Canada's nicotine caps will kill people(https://financialpost.com/opinion/opinion-health-canadas-nicotine-caps-will-kill-people)Jack M. Mintz: Raising tax rates to pay new debts may not work(https://financialpost.com/opinion/jack-m-mintz-raising-tax-rates-to-pay-new-debts-may-not-work)Open letter to Ottawa: This one small detail is hindering the cannabis industry's success(https://financialpost.com/opinion/open-letter-to-ottawa-this-one-small-detail-is-hindering-the-cannabis-industrys-success)What happens next?
If large tax increases follow in other provinces, tobacco tax revenues will no doubt plummet below forecast levels.
Finance estimated this increase will raise $2.135 billion in additional revenue over the next five years.
A Parliamentary Budget Office review lowered this to $2.04 billion.
But both assume no tax policy response from the provinces.

More seriously, more smokers will switch to readily available and far cheaper contraband products, which will be bad for the health side of policy, especially for young people since illegal sellers do not ask for proof-of-age ID.Ironically, Budget 2021 also announced the government's intention to introduce a new taxation framework for the imposition of excise duty on vaping products in 2022, saying it "will also work with any provinces and territories that may be interested in a federally coordinated approach to taxing these products.

"I would love to be a fly on the wall during those discussions.Fred O'Riordan is national leader for tax policy at EY and a former director-general for excise duties and taxes at the Canada Revenue Agency.
